hobby.message: You bring something banned books with you again?
Any new mods on your FPV quad?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Same boots, new dust, sure. Nothing really changes much these days.
Been out late flying drones. Just for practice, nothing special.
Harder to find clear air since the BCI crackdowns.
Still worth it, if you know where to look.
Yeah, dust settles differently, but I'm still drone flying when I can.
The last run got cut short—security keeps changing their patrol patterns.
Not easy slipping out with all these new checkpoints around.
Signal jammers make it tricky, had to reflash my kit after.
Still—FPV. Helps me focus.
Same old boots, same circuit. I fly FPV drones near the old stations.
Used to clear my head after work. Now, BCI patrols complicate things.
Last weekend, lost signal—almost lost the drone too.
Lots more scanners and moving sensors after the crackdown.
Still managed a tight run over the scrapyards.
Feels different, that's all.
Same boots get me to the best drone spots. FPV freestyle, mostly industrial outskirts.
Security updates forced me to swap radio modules again. Risky but worth the adrenaline.
BCI flagged my 'irregular movement' last night—dropped another point off my score.
The old transformer yard is crawling with new sensors. Had to bail, fast.
Still, that rush when you thread a gap at 70 kph—nothing else comes close.
Adapt or burn out, I guess.
Same city, different risks. I fly first-person drones—FPV, real low-level runs after midnight.
Been doing it since before the wristbands tracked stress responses. Used to be nothing but joy.
Now, every flight is cat-and-mouse with BCI sensor drones. I mask my controller, spoof my route.
Last week, nearly got caught—the system flagged me for irregular movement, shaved another point.
If I get too low, I lose my job, maybe vanish like my brother.
Still, I can't quit. It's how I stay sane in a city wired for compliance.
That moment of control, fifty meters up, fighting the algorithm—it's freedom.
Not much left that feels real anymore.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Swapped in new motors. Nothing fancy.
Tested them at home, not in the field.
Too many patrols after last week's detentions.
Signal sweeps are tighter. Not worth the risk lately.
Just tinkering, mostly.
Upgraded the signal filter on my quad. Helps, in theory.
Haven't flown far from home since the last crackdown.
Lost too many safe zones this month.
Half the regular spots are patrolled now, even at night.
Had to pause on testing new flight patterns.
Feels like every move gets flagged. Not the same.
Put a low-noise stack in. More stable footage, less chance to get flagged.
Tried it out by the river before the BCI sweeps ramped up.
Almost lost my drone when a patrol drone flew over last time.
The old industrial zone’s a no-go with Directorate sweeps lately.
Now I just fly quick and close to home. No repeats of that chase.
Kinda kills the fun, but I still get a rush.
Feels like the city's squeezing out any downtime.
Built a new carbon frame for better agility. Flies smoother than anything I’ve done before.
But those surprise patrols and data blackouts mess up my usual routes.
I tried going out the night after the Directorate sweep, had to mask the controller ID.
Almost got tagged coming back, BCI flagged me for 'irregular movement.'
Feels like every hobby’s treated like subversion now.
Had to rewrite the flight log files by hand to avoid more questions.
Honestly, for a few minutes up there, it was worth it.
But one slip and it’ll cost more than just a drone.
Started flying after my shifts just to clear my head—old habit from when my brother was here.
This month, rebuilt my quad from salvaged parts, nothing traceable to the registry.
The night after the big sweep, risked a low-altitude run out near the transformer piles.
Signal jammers forced me into dead zones—could hear patrol drones in the dark.
Had to wipe the quad’s history manually so nothing led back to me or anyone else.
My BCI dropped again from 'irregular activity.' They never say much but you always feel it.
Now I hand-wire flight controllers so nothing pings network scanners. Paranoid, I know.
Everyone’s tense—the city isn’t built for mistakes right now.
Still, for a couple seconds up there, it reminds me what freedom feels like.
